text: to February's Finance and Corporate, and we'll get on with it. So, I have apologies, apology from Councillor Barnes and for Mayor Milchrist for lateness. No other apologies.
speaker: loubrown

text: I'll move that, Andrew.
speaker: Unknown

text: You move. Thanks, Phil. Thanks, Blue. All in favour, please say aye. Aye. Contrary, no. It's carried. Disclosure of members' interests.
speaker: loubrown

text: I have one, obviously, Mighty River Domain.
speaker: lizstolwyk

text: Yeah, that's all good. You're on the other side of the table for once, so we'll look forward to that, cheers. Late items. Okay, there being none, we move on to confirmation of order and meeting. No changes, Ken? Not that I'm aware of, Andrew. Great, so could I have a mover, please? I'll move, Andrew. Thanks, Bruce. Thanks, Claire. All in favour? Aye. Contrary, no.  Carried. Confirmation of the minutes, which are on pages 8, 9, 10, 11, and sort of almost on to 12. Great, so there being no changes, could I have a mover? Clare and Elwyn, thank you. All in favour?  That's carried. And we'll move on to the Mighty River Domain 2021 Annual Report. Liz, the floor is yours.
speaker: loubrown

text: Yeah, thank you, Andrew. So I'm just going to swap seats and just have Phoebe Clark, who's my operations manager here at Mighty River Domain as well. So we're going to sort of just do this report together. So I'll take the report as read and I guess just talk about some of the highlights in there.  Obviously, we have had very little opportunity to run any events here at the Domain, given the COVID situation. But what I can say is that it has been very, very popular over the summertime. So what we've seen is our locals utilizing the Domain as a recreational reserve. And in fact, camping over Christmas and New Year, we had a large volume of people, 30% increase, which was really pleasing.  So I guess locals are just making use of their local reserve and of course using the hot weather as a great opportunity to pop out and you know and make the most of that. Good news is that we are going to be re-establishing a number of our events very shortly so later on this month we have the junior rowing regatta. Unfortunately no spectators but certainly the athletes are going to be able to come through and  and be actually able to row, which is really good. We've still got the Jet Ski Nationals and we've got the Waka Rama qualifying event a little bit later as well.  So yeah, the other good news is that we still have a number of weddings planned for April. Unfortunately, our conferencing is a little bit quiet, but hopefully once we get to a different alert level or different lights in the traffic light system, largely our conferences are over 100 people. So we really need that to change before we can get back to doing the work that we would normally do.  So that just gives you a bit of an idea of where we're at, and kind of where we're going forward. So happy to answer any questions. I'd like to offer better news, though I know the financials are looking very grim, but it is just the reality of the events in the hospitality sector at the moment. I think I'm blurry. Yeah, well, you and, sorry, your teammate who's, yeah, if you get, well, don't worry about it, we'll manage.
speaker: lizstolwyk

text: Okay. Yeah, look, your report was interesting and not unexpected, of course, and my comment is, considering the circumstance, I think you've done a really good job, so to have as much as you have had happen there, and really looking forward to hopefully some more normality for at least next summer. I think you're  Great Kiwi Summer Expo sounds like a fantastic idea, and I'm sure that will really go.
speaker: loubrown

text: Yeah, we were really excited to bring that in for 2022. It's a concept that we've been working on for a really long time. We've already made the call now not to run 2023, so the earliest we'll be able to run that event will be 2024.
speaker: lizstolwyk

text: Right, yep, good stuff. Okay, question, Bruce.  Thank you, Andrew.
speaker: loubrown

text: Liz, you say you've got a change, suggested changes to the site and that's enforcing the no dog policy or zone, but you're having problems doing it and no one's listening. How can you enforce it to make it get that point through? Because it's not, you obviously can't make it work at the moment. Signs aren't going to do it.
speaker: thomas

text: It's a really, really tricky one. So just yesterday I chased, you know, three people on site with three dogs off lead, and they were big dogs too. The message is not getting clear, coming clear. It's just unfortunately,  Yeah, really, really hard to manage. And given we've got 19 hectares here, even more difficult. You know, can't be eyes and ears everywhere. But look, we work with dog enforcement, animal control. And when we see something and if people aren't being, I guess, compliant and they refuse to be compliant, we do bring animal control in quite quickly. And they're brilliant. But the reality is we still have a lot of dogs coming on site on a daily basis. Signage doesn't really seem to work.
speaker: lizstolwyk

text: No. All right, that's not easy, all right.
speaker: Unknown

text: Ken, you've got your hand up, and then Marcus. You're muted, Ken.
speaker: loubrown

text: I was just saying, I don't believe I had my hand up, so, yeah. Oh, no, you don't, sorry. I'm happy to go straight to Marcus.
speaker: groupmanager

text: That was my cursor sitting in the middle of your screen, Marcus.
speaker: loubrown

text: I was just saying there's a great Kiwi summer expo they've got saying it's in 2023 not 24 on the promo stuff.
speaker: councillor

text: Oh did I get that wrong?
speaker: lizstolwyk

text: Yeah, so we're aiming for 2023, sorry, not 2022, when we'll be running. Right. Sorry, wrong again. So we're hoping to run October this year, but we've pushed it out another year just because of our ex-exhibitors and things been able to get stuck, and still that uncertainty. We thought a better launch year would be 2023.
speaker: lizstolwyk

text: Okay, cool. Thanks for that clarification.  Do I have any other questions for Liz? No? So... Andrew, I just wanted to say, a bit like you, I think you've done wonderfully well, Liz, and there's a whole lot of things closing down and you're still there and...
speaker: loubrown

text: you're looking vibrant and you've got ideas. And it's just, it's always a place to go to. And I think that 30% rise in people coming out to stay was probably locals coming from, you know, say Hamilton or something because they just didn't want to go, you know, too far further than home. Yeah.  Yeah, and like I said, we had just even locals from Karapero, our farming families, just popping over to stay for a week as well.
speaker: grahamewebb

text: It was a really good opportunity to sort of stay and play in your own backyard, I guess. Yeah, yeah. But look, just the other thing, just in finishing, and that is, look, all event venues, hospitality, accommodation providers in Waipā are struggling away. There's no doubt about that. I hear from a number of them.  there's no quick fix to this, unfortunately, whilst we're just having, you know, I guess, athlete only events and no spectators, that does not drive overnight accommodation. And we really need to see, you know, the aspect, the only way we, you know, our sector really enjoys the economic benefit is when people stay overnight, and we need that to be returned. Yeah, it's a pretty tough time out there.
speaker: lizstolwyk

text: Yeah, it definitely is. I can tell you even retail is really slowed up, and I don't think anything much is going to change until this Omicron wave goes through, however long that's going to take. And from one point of view, we want it over very quickly, and from another, we want to stretch it out so our hospitals and health systems not overwhelmed. So it's just a matter of being as patient as we can and hanging on, I guess.  But yeah, thanks for that. And I agree with you totally, Graham. I think Liz and your team, you're doing a great job. So thanks for that. I have a recommendation on page 13. Do I have a mover? That was Roger and Mike. Thanks. All in favour? Oh, sorry, Philip. I missed a question up there before we go through with that. Phil.
speaker: loubrown

text: Yep, it's not really a question, but thanks, Liz and Phoebe, for your report. Just you're talking about visitors, their eyesight's pretty quiet with people booking accommodation, but they are buying our retail stuff in the shop, so that's great for gifts. So thanks for your report, Liz and Phoebe.
speaker: Unknown

text: Cool, so that was moved. Roger, seconded Mike. All in favour?
speaker: loubrown

text: Aye.
speaker: susanoregan

text: Contrary, no.  That's carried. Thank you. Moving on to item seven, quarterly property services report. And I see John is front and centre. So, John.
speaker: loubrown

text: Good afternoon, everyone. This is a quarterly report till the 31st of December 2021.  Bruce pulled most of this together, but he left, finished on Thursday last week. So I think I might know a fair bit about it. So financials are pretty straightforward. Just goes through some of the others, Cambridge Museum seismic upgrades. So we need to re-roof the building and do some seismic upgrades with that building, pin the parapet back to the building.  and there's a few issues with the chimneys and that. So that works underway. The drawings are being submitted for a resource consent and the first draft. We've got drawings for the building consent. So that's in the process. We're looking at revising those procurement documents. Cambridge Water Tower, we've got feedback from  Heritage New Zealand, that we can remove the tank potentially and put up a piece of steel that purports to represent the tank. So we're working on that with Heritage New Zealand at the moment. Growth sales are ongoing. Got some reports later in public being excluded. Hicks Road, Mungatowtri, finally got  The walkway open on the 31st of December. Didn't make Christmas, but we made New Year, so finally got there. Mungatowtri Road cycleway easement, that's been sorted. So with the acquisition of 859 Mungatowtri Road, we've got access all the way now through to Waipuki. The Kiiki War Memorial Hall clock, the safe access systems have now been completed.  The clock's been, the clock working's been removed and the hand's been removed. The face has been refurbished and the clock mechanism should be put back up next week. And hopefully time will start again in Kiiki.
speaker: manager

text: It's looking fantastic as well. It's a massive improvement already over what it was looking like.
speaker: councillor

text: That's good. Pirongia, cycleway, I'll give you an update later on in the day on that.
speaker: manager

text: Mr. Chairman, can I just ask John a question about the extension of the cycleway? We've bought that property and we've got, we're in charge of the land going to Waipuki. When you're talking about coming back, you're talking about coming past the current houses between our new property and the end of the current cycleway?
speaker: grahamewebb

text: That's correct. There's a reserve for part of that.  that we can get in, and then 845 Mungatowtri Road, which is just past the starting line on the rowing course. We have agreement in place for that stretch through there. And then that adjoins 859 Mungatowtri.
speaker: manager

text: And John, any resistance to that, or they were happy to come on board with us?
speaker: grahamewebb

text: Maureen came to us actually, approached us with regards to trying to secure, she had the property on the market. So she came to us first to talk to us about that. So we were successful in negotiating that.
speaker: manager

text: Oh, fantastic. Great stuff. Good. Thank you.
speaker: grahamewebb

text: I entered MCIE, Motorhome Campus Association, Caravan Association at Te Amutu.  I've had an email from them in the last week or so. They were meeting on the weekend to approve their final design and plans. They're just about to lodge the resource consent for that site. We did have an onsite meeting, talked to the adjoining owners. We've reduced this site slightly, but I think they're still talking about 60 sites in there. So that's all progressing.  Franklin street in Peronga that demolitions underway. We've got a carpenter in there at the moment with an archeologist doing some work there. Asbestos is being removed this week and demolition scheduled to begin next week. Vale court, tin unit, pensioner housing expansion.  Um, we've fairly well got a documents, um, in a, in a state that is acceptable to everyone. Um, we're just giving some final information to M HUD ministry of housing and urban development with regards to, um, their model and rentals, um, current rentals for one bedroom units in, uh, Cambridge, uh, $380 a week.  So if we go down the path, we will get a better return on the properties we build and potentially land tenants will get income related rent subsidies. So we're working on that. I'd hope to have a report to council either probably April council meeting, hopefully to put that proposal to you.  Blundell Street properties that we're just tidying up. It's a boundary subdivision there, but that's pretty much it, I think. Plenty on the go.
speaker: manager

text: Yes, plenty on the go. Thanks, John. Do I have Claire and then Mike?
speaker: loubrown

text: Yeah, thanks, John. I've got a question about the Cambridge Town Hall Trust. It'd be really good to have an update from them on how they're going.  I'm not sure if Liz is working on that since she's asking about that earlier. But, you know, we haven't really heard anything from them since they were set up or anything.
speaker: clairestpierre

text: Ken's got his hand up.
speaker: manager

text: Yeah, through quickly through the chair.
speaker: Unknown

text: I think Ken's got a response to Claire's question. Yes.
speaker: loubrown

text: Yeah, so look, through the chair, look, the Town Hall Trust have been very actively working. In fact, I know that they had quite a significant strategic planning session over the weekend just gone. So, yeah, so Kirsty and the rest of the trustees are certainly fully engaged.  We have a draft lease and services agreement with the trust as well. So we drafted that up from the council side. That went to the trust, I believe, early to mid-December, and they've engaged some legal advice around that. So we are in close contact with Kirstie Johnson, the chair,  and actually as part of those conversations we have talked as well about the trust coming and presenting at a Finance and Corporate Committee meeting in the near future. But yeah, we were just hoping to get a bit further in terms of agreeing  that draft lease and services agreement, and of course, the strategic planning session that they've just had. But look, I would be hopeful that either March or April, we will be in a much better position for the trust to come along to one of these meetings and engage with you in regard to what they're up to. Greg Morgan Great.
speaker: groupmanager

text: Thanks, Ken. You got a comment on that, Liz? Liz Smith Yes.
speaker: loubrown

text: I was just going to say just to kind of  answer Claire's question.  The strategic planning, I was lucky to be part of that in my capacity as domain manager out here at Lake Karapeto. But the planning session was extremely well attended by a number of different user groups. And that, I think for me, was really heartening to see. So their ability to get out into the community and really, you know, what we were doing was just talking about, well, what does the community want for the town hall? How does it want to use the town hall going forward?  I was really heartened by the progress that I was able to see and very excited for the really bright future and hopefully a very bright future for the whole as well.
speaker: lizstolwyk

text: Thanks for that. OK, Mike.
speaker: loubrown

text: Yeah, thank you to the chair.  Just a question around the seismic work that needs to be done on the Cambridge Museum. And just, I guess, originally we probably didn't know the scope of it. Just the funding for that. How's it fitting in with what we'd planned, considering the roof, et cetera, now has to be done?
speaker: mikepettit

text: Yeah, I haven't got details on the budget, as I say, I haven't been involved with it lately, but I can certainly chase that up, Mike, and find out what the scope, what the estimate of the scope of works is and where our budget was. The works have to be done within 12 and a half years of when we gave notice to council of the IEP.  So, but the roof needs replacement, and it makes sense to do the pinning back of the parapet to the building at that time when the roof's off, and the same with the chimneys as well. So they're the two bits of work we're really looking at. Thanks, Nick.
speaker: manager

text: Okay, there's no further questions. I guess my only comment, John,  You've got a heap of work on and two staff members down. Yeah, there's nothing much we can do to help, I suppose, but hopefully you'll be able to fill those positions soon. Oh yeah, we're struggling at the moment with regards to filling positions, but yep. Ken, you've got a comment. 25 hours in a day, aren't there, Andrew?
speaker: loubrown

text: Yeah, so just through the chair, look, we have actually engaged a short-term resource to assist the property team. Admittedly, more at the management level, it's actually Chris Ryan, who is just retiring as the Chief Executive of Waitomo District Council.  So long-time local government chief executive obviously doesn't have specific property expertise, but look, we have taken Chris on just on a two-day-a-week short-term contract just to lend a bit of assistance for the team using his broad-based generalist local government management knowledge. But look, the market is really tight at the moment.  Yeah, we have basically advertised for the full-time manager position, but look, to date that hasn't yielded any suitable candidates, and it looks very much like our latest round for the facilities management property advisor position has, yeah, it looks like that has also failed. So, yeah, so look, it is a very tough market to recruit in at the moment.  Actually, Andrew, I'll just say as well, I think Susan had a question, if you want to go to Susan. Yes, yep, all good.
speaker: groupmanager

text: Yeah, you kind of addressed what my questions were around that staffing issue and what confidence were you able to give us in terms of filling those with suitably qualified and competent people, that's all.
speaker: loubrown

text: Obviously, they're pretty significant roles in our organisation. Obviously, massive loss to Lose Bros, but  you know, those facilities are the, you know, are interchanged with the community, right? So they need to, they're positions that we really need to have filled and filled really well. So yeah, watch the space. I hope you get some good applicants.
speaker: susanoregan

text: Yeah, I agree, Susan.
speaker: loubrown

text: The market is tight. You know, Waikato got a couple of similar roles at the moment. Rotorua looking for a property manager. You know, everyone's struggling.
speaker: manager

text: OK, well, I mean, I'm sure you're doing what you can, but as Susan says, I guess we will be watching the space with our fingers crossed. OK, so I have a recommendation on page 28 to accept John's report. Could I have a mover, please? Bruce and Graham, thanks. All in favour, please say aye. Aye. Contrary, no.  It is carried, and we will move to item eight, financial report, and I see Nada Deewa. Hi Nada, welcome. Hi, good afternoon everyone.
speaker: loubrown

text: I'll just take the report as read and just highlight some of the points as well. So currently the income is at 49% of the forecast,  and the operating expenditure is at 51%. We've got 59%.
speaker: manager

text: Sorry, Nath, I'm looking at something that says something slightly different, but... What are you looking at?
speaker: loubrown

text: We were about to hear you.
speaker: manager

text: Oh, no, I'm sorry. Yep, yep, that's all good.  Take it back. Sorry, carry on. OK, you're right.
speaker: loubrown

text: OK, so the subsidies and grants are at 59 percent of the forecast, and we have received about three point four million from the government for the Three Waters reform. And with the capital,  So you could see there that we've had all those annual plan changes go in. So I think there was quite a big reduction, about $47 million, that's come out of the capital with mainly the roading stormwater and wastewater.  And on page six on the key risk indicator report, just wanted to point out there that the additional lots measured there, that 101,  So that's a bit understated at the moment. So we're going to do some more work around that to get that cleared up and more accurate going forward. So they're just going to do some data cleansing on that. So in future reports, hopefully that looks like it's tracking better. Okay.  And then with the rates, we have a balance outstanding of 13.3 million, and that is after billing of the third installment, which is due on the 21st of Feb. And the water rates, we have had 8.1 million invoiced for the year, and we have an amount outstanding of 1.3 million. Was there any questions?
speaker: manager

text: Clare.
speaker: loubrown

text: Yeah, thanks Nada. The question I had is about the renewals and how they're really, you know, they're in red, you're not going to achieve them, which is like that's Gary's KPI to achieve 100% renewal. So what's the problem with that? And is there a plan to try and catch up or anything?
speaker: clairestpierre

text: I will look into that, but I'm picking that it might just be a timing, but I can have a look into that and I will get back to you to see how it's tracking. Yeah, and if it looks like, yeah. Yeah, thanks.
speaker: manager

text: Yes, we will probably get a much better idea of that with next month's forecast, but Ken, you've got a...
speaker: loubrown

text: Yeah, so just to say in that space, when you look at that key risk indicator report on page 43 of the agenda, you can see that that is actually red versus the growth and the level of service that are green.  But look, traditionally we do do pretty well in that renewals space. So yeah, so look, I'm sure that by the end of the year we will be a lot more advanced in that area. I suppose at the moment that is definitely showing as red. But yeah, but the team is always quite focused on delivering those renewals and generally we do do well in that space.  Yeah, so, yeah, so we do need to look at it as the chairman has just observed. Yeah, we are just about to do some budget and budget reforecasting, as we as we always do in February. So, yeah, so we'll have a much better idea the next time we present to you in March. Thanks, Ken.
speaker: groupmanager

text: OK, any further questions on the financials? No?  I've just got a little question. All of the requests for funding, which are quite substantial, are basically timing issues to do with the subdivision. So, yeah, I mean, they will end up being neutral to our finances in the long term. I thought I'd just make that comment.  But the recommendations A and B, which includes those funded requests, could I have a mover, please?
speaker: loubrown

text: Yes, I'll move. Roger, and thanks, Philip, for second.

text: All in favour? No. Contrary, no. That is carried. Thank you. So now we need a resolution to exclude the public. Do I have a mover? Marcus, thank you.  Thanks, Bruce. All in favour? Contrary no.
